awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Programmed Stimuli-responsive Mesoscale Polymers Inspired by Worm Blobs as Emergent Super-Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will support fundamental research aimed at developing novel materials composed of stimuli-responsive filaments. The long-term desired behavior of these materials is inspired by the behavior of 1-cm-long California blackworms (Lumbriculus variegatus, Annelida: Clitellata: Lumbriculidae), a fascinating organism that collectively self-assembles to form functional worm blobs.  The three-dimensional, soft, and tangled blob behaves as a living material that responds to environmental stresses through dynamic transformations of the blob’s morphology. The specific goals of this EAGER project are two-fold: to conduct biophysical experiments and mathematical analysis on living worms, and to synthesize soft, flexible, filament-like structures in polymer solutions. The behavior of both biological and synthetic systems will be studied at the level of individual filaments, pairs of twisted filaments, and collections of interacting structures. Understanding the properties and movements of these types of filaments has direct implications for creating novel materials, flexible robots, and objects that are pre-programmed to perform useful functions in response to external stimuli such as light, heat, or chemical reagents.  The research team will include students from diverse disciplines and under-represented groups, thus adding powerful educational impact to the project and enriching its societal and human impact. 

This EAGER project will synthesize worm-inspired pre-programmed filamentous structures in polymer solutions capable of exhibiting tangling and untangling dynamics in a triggered fashion.  While physically entangled filament-like structures are of great interest at both the molecular and macroscopic size scales, the interactions of structures of intermediate size, termed mesoscale, are not well understood. This project seeks to identify the chemistry, architectures, and most useful stimuli that enable collective systems of mesoscale polymers (MSPs) to readily tangle and untangle on command. Rudimentary segmental actuation of filamentous MSPs has been demonstrated by the research team. However, achieving intricate knotting and unknotting of collective filamentous structures remains a challenge. Here, chiral, twisting, and braiding mesoscale polymer structures will be synthesized using photochemical and fluid-induced methods. These efforts will be guided by fundamental research on the mechanics of knotting and unknotting in the living system. Together, these efforts could bring on a leap in materials synthesis while uncovering new foundational capabilities in the synthetic design of complex interacting filamentous structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative EAGER project investigated the dynamic self-assembly of living worm collectives and translated these insights into the design of programmable, entangled mesoscale polymers. Inspired by Lumbriculus variegatus (California blackworms), which can rapidly transition between tangled and untangled states, we studied the biophysical mechanisms underlying these behaviors and developed synthetic mesoscale polymeric materials that mimic their properties. The research integrated experiments, theory, and polymer engineering to explore how active, slender filaments interact to form adaptable, shape-changing structures. The results provide a framework for understanding topological transformations in active matter and open pathways for the development of bioinspired soft robotics and reconfigurable materials.

Intellectual Merit

This work advanced knowledge at the intersection of polymer physics, biomechanics, and active matter, with two key outcomes:

  1. Mathematical Models for Active Entangled Matter
    We combined ultrasound imaging, theoretical modeling, and simulations to uncover the physics of how blackworms form, maintain, and untangle dense, three-dimensional collectives. Our study in Science revealed that alternating helical waves—a resonant motion at the individual worm level—drive both tangle formation and ultrafast untangling. This work establishes a mechanistic understanding of how activity, elasticity, and topology govern the behavior of entangled living filaments, providing fundamental insights for designing synthetic topological active matter.

  2. Programmable Mesoscale Polymers with Tunable Properties
    In collaboration with the co-PIs, we fabricated high-aspect-ratio polymer ribbons that mimic the dynamic entanglement properties of worm blobs. A new evaporative deposition and dewetting process enabled the production of ribbons with tunable mechanical properties, spanning glass-like to elastomeric behavior (Soft Matter). These mesoscale polymers preserve their chemical fidelity and can be functionalized post-fabrication, allowing for pH-responsive shape transformations that mirror the rapid entanglement and disentanglement seen in biological worm blobs.

Broader Impacts

This project advanced the study of entangled active matter while also expanding public engagement, scientific communication, and interdisciplinary training. We developed multilingual comics, translated into Spanish and Thai, to communicate the physics of topological active matter to a broader audience. Outreach efforts included demonstrations at Zoo Atlanta and the Atlanta Science Festival, where we introduced living worms and bioinspired materials  to diverse communities. The project also provided direct training for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers, equipping them with expertise in biophysics, polymer science, and robotics through hands-on research and collaboration.
